row.entry: A re-usable, formal model of a concept expressed as a computable constraint model defined in ADL
ADL is a formal language for expressing archetypes. It provides a formal, textual syntax for describing constraints on any domain entity whose data is described by an information model
An initiative established to improve the interoperability of healthcare information systems through shared implementable clinical information models
Structured electronic communication made about a patient typically documented as an 'entry' in the patient record
A statement that is composed of parts where each part can only be fully understood in the context of its parent
A clinical statement composed of one or more clinical statements that may exist outside of the containing parent statement
A formal specification used for describing constraints on an Underlying Reference Model. The Constraint Model is used to express clinical information models (i.e. archetypes)
The circumstances that form the setting in which the ‘topic’ should be evaluated
A relatively small, standalone information model designed to express a precise clinical concept in a standardized and reusable manner
The use of a set of processes, customs, policies, laws and institutions to direct the way people administer
A model that, while different in structure, represents the same semantic content as a second model
The main concept of interest in a clinical statement, about which the other attributes and relationships provide additional information
Attribution information relating to the statement itself such as who authored, verified, recorded, or signed the statement. Meta includes the who, where, why and when information
The assertion of a relationship between the information model and the terminology
The clinical entity described by the Clinical Statement e.g. clinical assertions, evaluations results, and procedures
Attributes required to fully describe a clinical entity
